chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter is a hands-on tutorial that demonstrates how to synchronize the sample database between two running nodes of SymmetricDS.

To get started, you create a root (central source) database and a client (remote target) database that each run the SymmetricDS software to synchronize changes. You open registration for the client, which registers with the root to receive the synchronization configuration. You ask the root to reload the client in order to perform an initial synchronization. Then you make changes to each database and observe the changes propagating.

section.title: Installing SymmetricDS
section.para: Install the SymmetricDS software and configure it with your database connection information.

step.para:
Download the
symmetric-ds.zip
file from http://www.symmetricds.org/
Unzip the file, which creates a symmetric-ds-1.0.0 subdirectory.
Edit the database properties in the following property files for the root and client nodes:
Set the following properties in both files for the corresponding databases:
step.programlisting:
# The class name for the JDBC Driver db.driver=com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
# The JDBC URL used to connect to the database db.url=jdbc:mysql://localhost/sample
# The user to login as who can create and update tables db.user=symmetric
# The password for the user to login as db.password=

step.para: Set the following properties in the client.properties file:
step.programlisting: # The HTTP URL of the root node to contact for registration symmetric.runtime.registration.url=http://localhost:8080/sync

section.title: Creating and Populating Your Databases

important.para: You must first create the databases for your root and client nodes using the administration tools provided by your database vendor. Make sure the name of the databases you create match the settings in the properties files.

section.para: Create and load the root node tables with sample data and the synchronization configuration. Create the tables in the client node database to prepare it.

step.para: Open a command prompt and navigate to the samples subdirectory of your SymmetricDS installation.
Create the sample tables in both the root and client databases.
Note that the command may output warnings about altering foreign keys on the tables, which are safe to ignore.

Create the symmetric tables in the root node database. These tables will contain the configuration for synchronization. The following command uses the auto-creation feature to create all the necessary symmetric system tables.
Load sample data and configuration into the root node database.
Verify the databases by logging in and listing the tables.

section.title: Starting SymmetricDS
section.para: Start the SymmetricDS nodes and observe the logging output.

step.para: Open a command prompt and navigate to the samples subdirectory of your SymmetricDS installation.
Start the root node server.
The root node server starts up and creates all the triggers that were configured by the sample configuration. It listens on port 8080 for synchronization and registration requests.
Start the client node server.

The client node server starts up and uses the auto-creation feature to create the symmetric system tables. It begins polling the root node in order to register. Since registration is not yet open, the client node receives an authorization failure (HTTP response of 403).

section.title: Registering a Node
section.para: Open registration for the client node using the root node administration feature.

step.para: Open a command prompt and navigate to the samples subdirectory of your SymmetricDS installation.
Open registration for the client node server.
The registration is opened for a node group called "store" with an external identifier of "1".

Watch the logging output of the client node to see it successfully register with the root node. The client is configured to attempt registration each minute. Once registered, the root and client are enabled for synchronization.

section.title: Sending Initial Load
section.para: Send an initial load of data to the client node using the root node administration feature.

step.para: Open a command prompt and navigate to the samples subdirectory of your SymmetricDS installation.
Send an initial load of data to the client node server.

With this command, the root node queues up an initial load for the client node that will sent the next time the client performs its pull. The initial load includes data for each table that is configured for synchronization.
Watch the logging output of both nodes to see the data transfer. The client is configured to pull data from the root each minute.

section.title: Pulling Data
section.para: Modify data in the root database. The changes are propagated to the client database during pull synchronization.

step.para: Open an interactive SQL session with the root database.
Add a new item for sale to the root database

para.command: insert into item (item_id, price_id, name) values (110000055, 55, 'Soft Drink');

step.para: Once the statements are committed, the data change is captured and queued for the client node to pull.
Watch the logging output of both nodes to see the data transfer. The client is configured to pull data from the root each minute.
Verify that the new data arrives in the client database using another interactive SQL session.

section.title: Pushing Data
section.para: Modify data in the client database. The changes are propagated to the root database during push synchronization.

step.para: Open an interactive SQL session with the client database.
Add a new sale to the client database

para.command: insert into sale_transaction (tran_id, store, workstation, day, seq) values (1000, '1', '3', '2007-11-01', 100);
insert into sale_return_line_item (tran_id, item_id, price, quantity) values (1000, 110000055, 0.65, 1);

step.para: Once the statements are committed, the data change is captured and queued for the client node to push.
Watch the logging output of both nodes to see the data transfer. The client is configured to push data to the root each minute.
Verify that the new data arrives in the root database using another interactive SQL session.
